title: R41822
content: The 112th Congress is considering legislative proposals to limit the government's risk from Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, government-sponsored enterprises responsible for nearly half of the nation's outstanding residential mortgage debt. They purchase mortgages, pool and guarantee them into mortgage-backed securities, and sell them to investors or hold them as investments. In recent years, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were responsible for nearly half of the nation's residential mortgage debt. However, in 2008, their capital proved inadequate due to increased mortgage defaults and foreclosures, leading to higher borrowing costs. To support the mortgage markets during the financial crisis, the U.S. Department of the Treasury intervened to keep these enterprises in business. In 2008, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac faced capital inadequacy due to rising mortgage defaults and foreclosures. To support them during the financial crisis, the U.S. Department of the Treasury purchased over $175 billion in special preferred stock and the Federal Reserve bought nearly $1.4 trillion in mortgage-backed securities. The U.S. Department of the Treasury has purchased over $175 billion in special preferred stock to support enterprises in business. Treasury and the Federal Reserve have also provided mortgage market support by buying nearly $1.4 trillion in mortgage-backed securities. The enterprises are required to pay a 10% cash dividend on the Treasury funds, and their survival without continued support is uncertain. Some proposed bills may reduce the enterprises' future size by eliminating certain advantages. The enterprises are required to pay a 10% cash dividend on the Treasury funds. The proposed legislation, such as H.R. 1222, may increase costs for the enterprises, potentially leading to lower mortgage prices and higher interest rates for borrowers. Other bills aim to limit the types of mortgages they can purchase, increasing competition in the market. Some bills also focus on increasing regulatory oversight and disclosure. The bills, such as H.R. 31 and H.R. 1225, propose increased regulatory oversight, disclosure, and capital requirements to reduce risks. New SEC filing requirements would eliminate competitive advantages and align the enterprises with competitors. Additional legislative proposals aim to return the enterprises to stockholder control or dissolve them, phasing out their charters. (e.g., H.R. 408 / S. 178 and H.R. 1182 / S. 693) A fifth category of legislative proposals would replace the enterprises in the secondary mortgage markets (e.g. H.R. 1859 and H.R. 2413). The bills aim to set a deadline for the enterprises to return to stockholder control or be dissolved, phasing out their charters.
